1967 Ford Mustang
The Ford Mustang was a popular car in the 1960s and still is today. This great-looking 1967 Ford Mustang Coupe is an excellent example of why everyone loves these classics more and more with each passing year. This classic Mustang is finished in a deep blue metallic that contrasts perfectly with the black functional hood scoop and a black interior. The blinker hood is a very desirable factory option with built-in turn signals. The retro-cool look is enhanced with a set of 17-inch black American Muscle Bullitt wheels wrapped with 255/40ZR17 Sumitomo HTRZ performance tires. The clean interior is stock and original in appearance with a nice dash pad and black bucket seats. This Mustang also is equipped with the optional factory console and automatic floor shifter. An upgraded, retro-style steering wheel and a column-mounted Bosch tachometer have been added. Hidden in the glovebox is a Kenwood KKM-BT332U AM/FM/Bluetooth stereo for cruising enjoyment. The trunk features a high-quality custom fit carpet kit and side panels from Scott Drake. HIGHLIGHTS 289 V8 C4 automatic transmission 17-inch American Muscle Bullitt wheels Speedmaster intake manifold Brawler carburetor Aluminum radiator Dual exhaust Headers Front power disc brakes Kenwood stereo Pulling the hood pins and lifting the hood reveals a classic 289 cubic inch engine mated to a C4 3-speed automatic transmission. The engine features finned aluminum Ford Mustang logo valve covers, Speedmaster aluminum intake manifold, Brawler carburetor, power steering, Flamethrower coil, aluminum radiator and power front disc brakes. A set of headers rumble through dual exhaust with chrome tips. With classic Mustang style, numerous upgrades and in great condition, this stylish 1967 Ford Mustang Coupe is ready to enjoy. 1968 Ford Mustang
Vehicle Highlights include Rotisserie Restoration, California Special Edition, Chrome GT Style Wheels, GT Emblazoned Hubcaps, BF Gooderich Radial T/A Tires, Power Brakes, Front Disc Brakes, Power Steering, Factory Air Conditioning Car with Modern Unit Installed, Tilt Steering Wheel, Bucket Seats, Console, Windshield Squirters, Black Vinyl Roof, Dual Vented Hood Turn Signals, Dual Exhaust, Spare Tire, Jack, Trunk Mat, & Marti Report to confirm its authenticity. A Rare Gem in Mustang History, the California Special (GT/CS) was a special edition model introduced in 1968 as a tribute to the racing culture & performance-focused modifications found on the West Coast. Originally conceived for the California market, this model was produced in limited numbersmaking it one of the most coveted Mustangs in todays classic car community. Only 4,118 California Special Mustangs were ever built, making it a rare find for collectors and enthusiasts alike. With its striking good looks & powerful engine options, this 1968 California Special is one of the most sought-after versions of the Mustang, & one that has appreciated in value over the years. Painted in the sought-after Candy Apple Red with Black Vinyl Roof & Black Decals with a Black Interior. At the heart of the 1968 California Special Mustang is the raw power of Fords Legendary 289 V8 2V delivering 195hp & paired to the C4 3 Speed Automatic Transmission. Key Features of the California Special Edition include Fiberglass Trunk Lid & Quarter Extensions (similar to the Shelby GT500s), Horizontal 65 Thunderbird Tail Lights (Non-Sequential), Special Pop-off Gas Cap, Horizontal Stripe on Tail, Fiberglass Side Scoops, California Special Script Badging on Back Rear Fenders, Body Side Triple Decal Stripe (Starting on Front Fender Edge to Rear of Side Scoop), GT/SC on Side Scoop, Blacked out Front Grille with Dark Grey Metallic Surround, Rectangular Lucas Fog Lights, & Competition Style Hood Locks. The Paint has been Buffed & Polished to a Mirror Finish, the Chrome & Brightwork is in excellent condition, the Glass is clear, & the Vinyl Roof is tight & like new. In the Interior, the Upholstery is tight & clean, the Carpet is like new, the Headliner is tight, the Dash is crisp & free of crack, & the Gauges are like new. The Engine Compartment is nicely detailed with paint finishes & even the warning decals. Finally, the Undercarriage is detailed & painted like it was new. This particular 1968 California Special Mustang has been meticulously maintained & restored to preserve its classic charm & authenticity. From the glossy finish of its vintage paintwork to the interiors original touches, everything about this Mustang is quality & care. This Mustang drives & feels as good as it looks. Come on down to Munro Motors & see this one for yourself, its in stock. We will look forward to seeing you real soon! Yes we take trade in vehicles. 1969 Chevrolet Camaro
Gateway Classic Cars of Orlando is proud to present this 1969 Chevrolet Yenko Camaro Tribute. Yenko's story is legendary, and prices on real Yenko vehicles bear out his wonderful legacy of high performance and factory-built horsepower. With prices spiraling ever higher on pedigreed examples, the smart hobbyist who likes driving his hardware buys a tribute car like this Garnet Red 1969 example. With the same fire-breathing 427 under the hood, the dazzling Yenko graphics package it's the ultimate drivable dream.Code 52 Garnet Red is one of the handful of hues that were offered on the originals, lending this car some additional authenticity. There are, of course, the bright white body stripes with Yenko S/C (for 'Super Car') callouts on the quarter panels, but there are also a myriad of badges advertising the thumping 427 under the hood, as well as a lovely Yenko badge affixed under the stock Camaro script on the front fenders. Under the hood is 1969 vintage L72 427 under the hood, which according to the owner has been rebuilt to factory specs including 11 1 compression with forged aluminum pistons and closed chambered heads, Factory aluminum intake manifold cast correct for L72 engines, 750 Holley carb and more. Paired with a M22 Rock Crusher 4-speed Muncie transmission Imagine how this Yenko can get up and go! There's simply nothing like keying up that legendary 427. The sound, the feeling of the idle, and the relentless surge of torque as you power through the gears. Even back in the day these were legitimate 12-second cars, and even today's world of 600 horsepower Corvettes, performance is impressive. If you're looking for an impressive tribute that may fool even the keenest Yenko aficionado this is the one you want to own! Options include AM/FM radio, spare tire, power brakes, power steering, houndstooth interior, seat belts, and alloy wheels wrapped in white letter bias ply tires. Category 1969_chevrolet_camaro

1964 1/2 K code mustang coupe. This very early production K code coupe was produced on June 10th 1964, the 10th day of Hi Po 289 production. Single ownership from 1993 until 2024, over 30 years! Solid AZ car that was restored under its previous owners care who was an avid Mustang enthusiast and club member. Refinished in its original color of Wimbledon white with matching white interior, code 46. (“white with black trim”) All of the chrome and stainless looks good with some pieces only showing some minor aging but certainly no pitting anywhere, consistent of a southwest car. Paint looks great and was refinished to a factory appearance, not overdone as many “show cars” are restored today. All of the glass is original and in very nice shape with original factory markings. Windshield has one very small chip on the passenger side. The interior is very nice showing little wear. Refinished in the correct factory white with black trim. Seat belts have been fitted in the front seats only. All of the gauges work including the Rally Pac Tach. Clock is inoperative. AM FM radio works great. Heater and wipers work, as do all of the interior and exterior lighting. All weatherstrips and seals were replaced when restored and are in good condition. The 289 Hi Po engine runs amazing and sound even better with its solid lifter tappets. Upgraded with genuine Shelby Cobra intake and valve covers with a Carter “Competition Series” 600 cfm Carburetor with manual choke. Exhaust manifolds were Cerakote’d and the dual exhaust runs Dynomax mufflers. Engine is backed by an upgraded T-5 super HD 5 speed overdrive although I still retain the original style toploader 4 speed if the new owner prefers the original it can be included with the car. The car retains its original Ford 9″ differential with 3.50 standard gear. Rolls on chrome styled steel rims with Cooper “Cobra” radials. In addition to the Shelby Cobra engine mods the car was also upgraded with lowered front A-Arms as the 66 Shelbys were, front and rear sway bars, KONI shocks, and 4 piston disc brakes up front. The car has an export brace and Monte Carlo Bar. I spent a day running errands in this car and can assure you it has tons of power. handles great, and is truly a fun car to drive! Hard to beat a factory K code mustang! Worldwide shipping available, please email me for a Quote. More Pictures and FINANCING available on my website www.TucsonClassics.com Thanks! Anthony Category 1965_ford_mustang

Looking for a project or you and your kids or grandkids? This 1965 Ford Bronco more than fills the bill. This project does start, run and drive around a parking lot. Note The brakes do not function. Made in Ford's Wayne Michigan assembly plant in August 1965, this compact sport-utility vehicle is dressed in white over Sahara Beige (code H). The paint and trim are in satisfactory order, while the car's bodywork is straight. The chrome bumpers fit tightly to the body but are in similar condition to the rest of the vehicle's exterior. The hinged windshield folds down. This is a very early production number of the first year bronco was offered. This Bronco rolls on a mix of radials, size 275/75R15 at all four corners. The truck has no wheel covers, just steel wheels with front locking hubs and Equa-lock axle. There is a full-sized spare tire in the back. The tires and wheels are all in poor condition. It rides on a 92-inch wheelbase and has a 3,900 GVWR. For 1966, three Bronco body configurations were offered, including a two-door wagon, a half-cab pickup and an open-body roadster. Under the hood is a 170 CID 12-valve straight six-cylinder engine backed by a floor-mounted three-speed manual transmission and a 3.20 1 rear end. To lower production costs, at its launch, the Bronco was offered solely with a three-speed, column-shifted manual transmission and floor-mounted transfer case shifter. To simplify production, all examples were sold with four-wheel drive; a shift-on the-fly Dana 20 transfer case and locking hubs were standard. The rear axle was a Ford nine-inch unit, with a Hotchkiss drive and leaf springs; the front axle was a Dana 30. The vin plate (detached) does match the vin stamping on right front frame member. Inside, the truck's front buckets are in poor shape, there's no carpeting and the headliner is in similar shape. There's an original two-spoke steering wheel framing the original dashboard. The original inner door liners, the dash and steering wheel are all worn out. A factory AM radio completes the interior. The idea behind the Bronco began with Ford product manager Donald N. Frey in the early 1960s (who also conceived the Ford Mustang) and was engineered by Paul G. Axelrad, with Lee Iacocca approving the final model for production in February 1964, after the first clay models were built in mid-1963. Developed as an off-road vehicle (ORV), the Bronco was intended as a competitor for the Jeep CJ-5, International Scout and Toyota Land Cruiser. Today a compact SUV in terms of size, Ford marketing shows a very early example of promoting a civilian off-roader as a Sports Utility (the two-door pickup version). Competition to this Ford in 1966 included Jeep's CJ-5, International's Scout 800 and Toyota's Land Cruiser. If you like restoring 4x4 vehicles and you've never had a first-generation Ford Bronco in your garage, this is your opportunity to restore one. Popularly known as “K-code”—in reference to the special letter designation in the VIN of Mustangs so equipped — the package included a 289 cubic-inch V-8 engine rated at 271 horsepower and a medley of performance items for a whopping $442.60. The car’s solid-lifter V8 was not the average Ford small-block. Inside its over-square, four-inch cylinder bores were high-strength flat-top aluminum pistons. These were linked via heavy-duty connecting rods with strengthened rod bolts to a more robust cast-iron crankshaft with an enhanced front counterweight to maintain high-rpm balance. Each cylinder head had enlarged intake and exhaust valves, while the engine breathed through cast-iron, header-type manifolds and into a standard dual exhaust system. A Special Handling Group helped make the most of all the power with heavy-duty shocks, springs, and a front sway bar. This '68 Yenko Camaro tribute received a stunning frame off restoration. You don't see a 68 Yenko, it stands apart from the others. A new ZZ502 Crate engine elevates it to the next level. Additionally custom TMI buckets, custom gauges and a top quality paint job provide unprecedented style and comfort. Fresh with only 1,230 miles since completion. We acquired this from a fussy collector. I look forward to his phone call with something for sale! Any angle you look at her from, she is pretty and powerful and ready to hit the streets! EXTERIOR Exceptional body and paint work! The Cortez Silver paint has just the right amount of flake to make it shimmer and is laid out perfectly. It's seriously polished like a piece of glass, so smooth and slick. The black stripe is properly done to factory dimensions. Looking down the side of the arrow straight body is satisfying thanks to the smooth contours and crisp lines. The panels are very nicely aligned with gaps that are well above average. The spoilers and hood scoop really enhance the profile. Everything up front looks spotless, it even has correct T3 headlights. Yenko badges pay homage to the original. The windshield and rear window are new. The rubber seals and fuzzy strips were even replaced. The bumpers and remaining trim pieces all have a glorious shine. It's equipped with dual side mirrors and the door ledge moldings too. It has the ideal stance and is rolling on 15 Rally II Wheels which is what Yenko used in 1968. They even have Yenko center caps and new polished rings. They are wrapped in a set of reproduction BFG radial redline tires. INTERIOR Completely refinished top to bottom using mostly brand new parts! It is upgraded with digital/analog gauges from Dakota Digital and reclining sport buckets by TMI. The seats are very comfortable and trimmed like the original with modern touches. The headliner, dash pad, steering column, steering wheel, door panels, handles, levers, visors, mirror, gauge bezel, center console, shifter, glove box liner, rear shelf and carpeting are all new. It also has a new retro looking stereo that fits in the factory hole and a Kicker 4x10 dash speaker plus 6x9s in the back. ENGINE COMPARTMENT GM Crate ZZ502 making 502hp and 580 lbs of torque! Enjoy all that brute power knowing it has the ultimate in reliability. We have the paperwork on this engine, it was purchased new 11-23 and only 1,230 miles have been put on it. It comes with aluminum heads and intake and an HEI ignition. A new dual feed Holley carb and a set of coated Doug's headers were installed. It features a few upgrades including hydroboost power steering and a power brake system. It also has a new radiator and clutch fan. Upgraded DSE wiper system. A Delco battery topper and reproduction spring clamp cables add a nice vintage look. The underside of the fiberglass hood, fenderwells and firewall are all neatly painted satin black. TRUNK COMPARTMENT The underside of the trunk lid and jamb are nicely painted like the exterior. It has reproduction stickers and the weatherstrip was replaced. Inside is all rust free and solid metal with a coating of black paint and a new rubber mat. It also has a new tire and painted rim for a spare tire and the jack assembly. UNDERSIDE Very nice! The steering was rebuilt and works great. Springs and shocks were replaced up front plus it has a swaybar. The leaf springs out back also look fresh and have new hardware too. The brakes have been completely rebuilt and even the emergency brake is hooked up, they are disc upfront. Long tube headers and a stainless Flowmaster exhaust system have this monster sounding mean. The gas tank and all the lines were replaced. Looking up at the motor it has a Milodon extra capacity oil pan. The flywheel cover, trans pan and rear end cover are a matched set; a very cool looking finned aluminum painted black with polished find. The Turbo 400 automatic trans was serviced, a new torque converter was installed. It also has a 12 bolt rear end with new 3.42 posi gears. The floors are solid and rust free with neatly applied black paint. SERVICE Our shop manager thoroughly inspected this car and we replaced the center console, shifter and trim rings on the wheels. We also lubed the left rear window, adjusted the exhaust and balanced the wheels. This killer machine with a raging 502 V8 has got what it takes to be the boss! The looks are killer too. If you're in the market for a Camaro that was built to be driven without regret, buying one of fussy Joe's cars is what you want. This one ticks all the boxes! GR Auto Gallery is proud to present this stunning 1969 Chevrolet Camaro Z/28 RS, a pinnacle of American muscle car engineering and design. Introduced as part of the Camaro's first generation, the Z/28 option was Chevrolet's response to the Trans-Am racing series. It was designed specifically for competition, with its high-revving 302 V8 engine, providing an ideal balance of power and handling to meet the series' 5.0-liter displacement limit. Coupled with a manual transmission, this Z/28 RS offers the raw driving experience that enthusiasts seek. The Rally Sport (RS) package brings distinctive cosmetic upgrades, including the signature hideaway headlights, unique grille, and chrome accents, which add an extra layer of style to the Z/28's aggressive performance-focused design. This particular example has been meticulously restored by Antique Auto Restorers, with just 10,000 miles driven since its full restoration. The total mileage on the car is 86,000 miles, indicating that it has been well-preserved over the decades. Dressed in Hugger Orange with black racing stripes, this Camaro's striking exterior is complemented by a beautifully maintained black leather interior. The combination of the Z/28's racing pedigree and the RS package's sleek styling makes this car a true standout, not just in terms of performance but also visual appeal. Chevrolet only produced a limited number of Z/28s, and even fewer with the RS package, making this car a rare find for collectors. The Z/28's 302 V8 engine, originally developed for racing, is known for its ability to deliver high RPM performance while maintaining excellent handling, making it one of the most desirable Camaros of all time. On the track, the Z/28 earned its reputation as a fierce competitor, helping Chevrolet secure victories in the SCCA Trans-Am racing series. Whether you're looking to dominate at car shows or take this muscle legend for a thrilling drive, this 1969 Camaro Z/28 RS represents the peak of Camaro performance and style during the golden age of American muscle. By 1969, Chevrolet’s first-generation “F-Body” Camaro had truly come of age, with strong sales driven by its handsome styling, huge option list and brilliant racing success. Conceived and built with development spearheaded by Chevrolet’s Vince Piggins as the GM division’s new SCCA Trans-Am racing contender, the RPO Z28 option package was quietly introduced for the Camaro in 1967 to homologate the car for racing. Careful refinements for 1968 and 1969 further enhanced the concept, with the latter showing a slightly restyled front and rear. At its heart, the Z28 featured a high-winding and tough small-block V-8 engine, combining the basic dimensions of the 327 cylinder block and short-stroke 283 crank to yield 302 CI—just inside the SCCA-mandated displacement limit for Trans-Am racing. Carefully developed underpinnings and other race-inspired tweaks maximized the factory-underrated 290 HP output of the Z28. Extensive nut and bolt restoration! 1970 Chevrolet Camaro Z28 Hardtop 1970 saw the introduction of the all new Second Generation Camaro. The 1st generation Camaro, (1967-1969), was seen as a hasty response to the Ford Mustang. It was considered a compromise by some critics. There would be no compromises with this car. Due to production delays the 1970 Camaro was introduced in February 1970, halfway into the production year. Because of this, some people will call the 1970 Camaro a 1970 1/2, but officially the car is a 1970 model year Camaro. Good things come to those who wait, and this car was met with rave reviews from nearly everyone. Chevrolet had a winner that would run for 12 years. Thx tonastyz28.com For consignment, a 1970 Chevrolet Camaro Z28 hardtop with the Vee shaped grille and split bumpers, a desirable feature that came as part of the RS package on Z28's. It's got classic F-body lines, wide double stripes, and a later era 350ci V8 under the hood. Exterior Dark Blue Metallic doesn't look bad on too many cars and it looks great on this one, especially with the complementary white stripes that traverse over the raised hood, the decklid, and up and over the rear spoiler which leans back to shed the wind. The gaping egg crate grille has a metal surround while the round turn signals are an RS cue, looking great behind clear lenses. Holes for hood pins are in the hood which has a raised cowl flanked by dual sport mirrors. Out back, muscular quad tail lights sit below the spoiler while the chrome bumper contours around the license plate cove and a pair of exhaust tips split wide and finish up the symmetrical rear of the car. 15-inch Chevrolet SS wheels in charcoal look great and wear staggered size tires. The paint coverage is very nice, and we note a few imperfections including a ding on the top of the left front fender and some bubbling at the bottom corner of a door. Interior A plastic header tops the door panels which are constructed of stitch patterned black vinyl and the driver's side shows some separation of the insert while the passenger side is in good shape. Textured black vinyl covers the front bucket seats which are flat by today's sport standard but are in great shape and include a headrest. In the back, the same material is used for the 2+2 seating, and it looks showroom fresh, as do the molded plastic sidewalls. A 3 spoke steering wheel leads to a dash that is canted on the sides towards the center, creating a cockpit vibe and housing numerous gauges, knobs, and switches and a few holes exist where items are missing, and this includes the radio. A Hurst shifter is floor mounted, rubber booted, and surrounded by black loop carpet in good shape. The headliner has some looseness but is fully intact and the trunk is completely barren. Drivetrain Pop the hood and a show quality power plant greets you in the form of a rebuilt 350ci V8 from 1979, fueled by a 4-barrel sitting on top of an Edelbrock intake manifold. The valve covers and air filter cover are also Edelbrock products while bright red wires lead to the sparks and match the MSD ignition box on the firewall. A polished alternator and headers also add some eye candy to the engine bay. Backing it up is a rebuilt Muncie M20 4-speed manual transmission referring power to the 10 bolt axle out back with 2.56 gears. Power disc brakes live up front and power drums reside in the back. Underside The theme here is a little bit of everything amongst the otherwise clean underside. A little bit of surface rust. A little bit of oil on the pan and transmission. A little bit of road dirt but not much. Happily, there's not even a little bit of invasive rust. Meanwhile, the dual exhaust enters a pair of Flowmaster mufflers before exiting out back and suspension consists of coil springs up front and leaf springs with traction bars out back. Drive-Ability No complaints here as the V8 fires right up, sounds great, and moves this Z in fine fashion and with plenty of gusto. Handling is great, tracking is straight, and the brakes work as they should. Things that don't work include the horn, the heater blower, the wipers, the reverse lights, and the clock. All other functions work as expected. While Classic Auto Mall represents that these functions were working at the time of our test drive, we cannot guarantee these functions will be working at the time of your purchase. Here's a spicy little dish with all the right ingredients. F-body, Z28, split bumpers, racing stripes, a wing, a manual transmission, dual exhaust, and lovely dark blue paint. FIRST GENERATION MUSTANG PONY PACKAGE Close-up image of the “running ponies” embossment on classic Mustang seatsh The name Ford gave to the Pony Package in 1965 was the “Interior Decor Group.” It wasn’t a name that really suited the Mustang, and owners quickly started referring to it as the Pony Interior. It gained this nickname because of the embossed ponies that were on the backs of the seats. The Pony Package is considered a desirable feature for collectors, and definitely adds value to first-gen Mustangs. Based on the Pony Interior’s lasting popularity, it’s surprising it was only offered for two years. Since then, enthusiasts have restomodded their first-gen Mustangs to also have Pony Interiors.
